Topic.Title: Very Important Facts About Amazon and LivingSocial

Message.Msg: It does show up on the income statement as "Equity investment method" .. AMZN has to value its investment in them each Q and place the value change in the income statement. Anytime a company owns 20% or more of something that have to inlcude the valaution in their financials. in teh 1st three Q's of 2012, they claimed a $110M loss in that investment. Look for it continue to take losses, as I hear living social is not doing well and they laying off employees.

Topic.Title: Puts Now

Message.Msg: Am Impressed!!!

Topic.Title: Very Important Facts About Amazon and LivingSocial

Message.Msg: I don't think it has anything to do with whether they take losses, it has to do with the market value piece of Living Social which probably has increased like GRPN off the raging market rally lows since Nov 16. So they could see a writeup and no a writedown on that basis. It's about the company's valuation, not what they made.

Topic.Title: How high do we go before the selloff?

Today was the day by prospec5.Oct 28, 2003 5:19 PM.Permalink . when the weak hands in the bearish camp (correct on the driection for the intermediate term, but too early on the short term) have thrown in the towel. This leaves only net selling now for a few weeks or months. the market has been irrational and the chickens have come home to roost. The main thing driving this market the last few months has been fear of missing the major up trend. Well, guess what, the market will fool the masses again and go down now that almost everybody thinks it has to go up for the next 5 years.

Topic.Title: When is the last time amzn was downgraded due to excessive valuation?

Message.Msg: doesn't get downgraded on that. It gets downgraded at big correction lows , if you want to base what analysts do at certain price points. The last signicant downgrade by big banks came at 40-50 AMZN in late 2008 lows. Banks don't downgrade AMZN that much , they raise price targets once the last ones arre met. They are retro-reactive,not pre-reactive. Nobody there dares put their career on the line downgrading AMZN as it goes up like a rocket for years as a WS fav.

Topic.Title: When is the last time amzn was downgraded due to excessive valuation?

Message.Msg: It has nothing to do with the valuation on upgrades /downgrades. Analysts don't work fro you : they work for the funds as clients. it seems to me you don't get how the anlaysts relationship to AMZN over the years. it's you who doesn't understand : you think they do the right thing. Its' about selling the story, not the valuation: show me one downgrade in AMZN by a banks/brokerage you know since AMZN has run off the last correction: you won't and only find target increases when the last ones are met. Now if AMZN ever has a bad stock reaction, then you might see an analyst FOLLLOW the down action with negative comments. Your idea of how WS anlaysts works is too righteous. They are not in the business to be rightious to you .

Message.Title: Everyone knows AMZN will fall HUGE. We just don't know what day it starts
Message.Msg: Sometimes it can happen on earnings like it did for apple and other times it just is random. AMZN will have its day and once the cards fall it will be big. Bigger than Apple or Netflix ever were. AMZN's lack of margins at best could offer it a wal-mart like multiple say 13 to 15. Amazon will have to constantly spend money to grow revenue. They simply need as much warehouse space as their revenue growth so the scaling never happens. The only time spending can stop is when growth stops but we know what happens then right? I see the free pass to Bezos ending sometime. Could be tomorrow, next week, next month or next year but it will happen. When it does we'll see a stock price between $20 and $50 per share. Most likely on the lower end of that range.

Topic.Title: Everyone knows AMZN will fall HUGE. We just don't know what day it starts

Message.Msg: I am not short for this reason. Too hard to call and too dangerous. I sold my long shares around 240. Just going to watch from the sidelines as I'm 100% positive a 75% plus fall is coming. I can't predict when as I said so can only sit on the side and watch the train wreck once it starts. Once it falls say 50% I'll maybe go long with some PUTS as it won't come back from that damage and should fall another 50% from there. I'll wait whether it starts tomorrow, next month, next year or longer. Amazon cloud services are also capital intensive and low margin commodity. Seems most investors do not know this. Amazon tries to hide it by not breaking out numbers as well. So much competition in this space there is no pricing power and lock in to ecosystems in the cloud are giving way to easily transportable environments. Amazon won't go out of business but soon people will realize the lack of earnings power, low margins, continued losses and the holy grail of "someday" this will all pay off is not coming. Not unless bezo's does a Jobs and invents some major new category of something with 45% margins. Right now he plays in the 1% to 3% margin playground. Not a great business. Don't believe me? Look at every earnings report since they went into business 15 years ago. Now this "startup" is STILL LOSING MONEY

Message.Title: I exited

Message.Title: AMZN is Just as Much "Bricks and Mortar" than WMT and Best Buy
Message.Msg: With all these warehouses they are building to house merchandise and fulfill orders, they are no better off than the big box stores. And they have shipping costs that its peers don't. They already have razor thin margins and it wont get any better anytime soon. At best, they save a little on wharehouse space cost vs. retail space but to the point of being over 100X more expensive than Walmart ?!? Anyways, as AMZN grows so does their need form "Bricks and Mortar" and it will never "grow into" these insane valuations. If you want a play on e-commerce, EBAY has a way better business model.

Topic.Title: Everyone knows AMZN will fall HUGE. We just don't know what day it starts

Message.Msg: You don't have to lose $ just because you're wrong. I have an old short position where I write covered puts against my short position to generate cash and hold the balance to offset future gains from other winners. For new bear ideas, I prefer to write bearish vertical option spreads. I tend to agree with the bulls in that fundamentals don't seem to apply to AMZN. People see what they want to see. One quarter their earnings was completely based on foreign exchange and the spin was overseas sales and the analysts were bullish on the news. A few quarters later they took a loss and they blamed it on foreign exchange conversion rates and the analysts saw that as bullish too.

Topic.Title: Everyone knows AMZN will fall HUGE. We just don't know what day it starts

Message.Msg: No single person controls or nor a consortium. This is just "herd" psychology. I was a psych major which actually makes investing easy when you know how people are likely to react and act. Fear and Greed. Fight or Flight. Once the fall begins the hard wired fear and flight kick in. It becomes overwhelming. Look at apple. Sellers dumping this at 6 times earnings ex-cash and it can still drop another 30%! Only thing that matters to people is preservation at any cost once the tumble begins. Amazon could see this tomorrow. Earnings are the highest likelihood for the spark that ignites. It could be this one or next one or a future one. We'll just have to wait and see when the free pass for Bezos gives out and panic starts. Maybe Apple spooked some to see what is possible especially in a cheap stock. Now they have a hyper expensive stock with little earnings prospects. This is going to be a huge fall...

Topic.Title: Everyone knows AMZN will fall HUGE. We just don't know what day it starts

Message.Msg: the thought with AMZN is that Bezos controlling so much stock allows it to be more easily supported. AAPL had too mancy shares in too many hands and was run to 700 + with great number of hedge funds owning it. Doesn't mean AMZN can't fall. : but it's not overowned in the hands of too many. That might explain how AAPL and AMZN valuation separted long ago and AAPL cracked while AMZN still has gone hgiher. Just a thought. AAPL was spooked well before this earnings report while the stock of AMZN didn't bat an eye lash to it. You make some good points. Gonna be very interesting. good luck.

Topic.Title: AMZN is Just as Much "Bricks and Mortar" than WMT and Best Buy

Message.Msg: Exactly. Amazon is A to B to consumer just like retailers, except retailers have the consumer do the pick-pull of inventory at point B. AMZN's supply chain superiority is smoke and mirrors. The numbers don't lie.

Topic.Title: Everyone knows AMZN will fall HUGE. We just don't know what day it starts

Message.Msg: Some other interesting facts about where amazon is and where it can go if you are a long. Amazon Market Cap: 125B (EPS 0.08) WalMart Market Cap: 232B (EPS 4.86) So if you think Amazon can someday bring their earnings up to walmart's you might have a double from here. Looks like alot more downside risk vs upside. Figure 90% downside and maybe 2x upside. I do not believe Amazon will see those kinds of earnings in the next 2 decades if they even will in their lifetime. So what if Amazon burns billions over the next 10 years before they start making money? Say 50 billion torched. They have to make 50B in profit just to offset those losses and become net profitable. Amazon also is not a titan like Apple. Amazon has just 5B in cash versus 137B to apple. A 132B difference there. Amazon's EBITDA is just 2B for the trailing twelve months. That is EBITDA! Apple made 14 billion in NET PROFIT last quarter. 7 times Amazons ANNUAL EBITDA. So apple trades for just a little over THREE TIMES Amazon's market cap now. The lesson will be that valuations don't matter....until they do...and then can you get out fast enough? Maybe you wake up one morning and the stock will open premarket at 100/share. You can't even get out and your stop losses won't take you out. If you are long AMZN pat yourself on the back. You got some guts here

Topic.Title: Everyone knows AMZN will fall HUGE. We just don't know what day it starts

Message.Msg: They barely break-even. WS is playing the game of "they're in these hot new businesses that are sure to takeoff, so we'll hold on." Don't you have to have earnings to justify a stock price Oh? Maybe you don't. Just look at Workday(WDAY) Everytime they ink a contract, it's for a loss. Of course, trying to compete against Oracle, SAP and Salesforce is causing that. And, Ellison, who bought out the WDAY founders when he tookover People Soft, has an ax to grind. The stock has a MC of $9 bilion and they lose $50 million on every $100 million of sales. Kind of a dumb way to run a business. Amazingly, some brokers are putting out buys at higher prices. They must be trying get their customers out of the IPO was sold despite dubious prospects.

Topic.Title: AMZN is Just as Much "Bricks and Mortar" than WMT and Best Buy

Message.Msg: "If you want a play on e-commerce, EBAY has a way better business model." An option is to buy and keep both EBAY and AMZN. They're different and they can co-exist. EBAY represents the biggest online flea market, and AMZN represent the biggest online shopping mall.

Topic.Title: Assymetric risk favors the bears imho

Message.Msg: "$350 that's a $75 rise for over 30% gain are you serious?" Nobody would get shocked if AMZN went to $300 on Wednesday. That's what I'm saying. In order to encourage more trading, something shocking will have to happen. The shocking thing could be a move to the downside. I wouldn't be surprised to see AMZN below $230 either.

Topic.Title: AMZN is Just as Much "Bricks and Mortar" than WMT and Best Buy

Message.Msg: A bad option, but an option nonetheless. EBay has vastly superior economics. Amazon is now a logistics company being valued as a secular technology grower typified by high margins and significant network effects. This will prove to be a bigger bubble than CSCO at its peak.
